bibl.title: Letter from Darrell C. Crain to Philip Showalter Hench, March 30, 1942

div1.p: Crain writes that he has received the enlargements sent by Hench and the framed Cornwell painting reproduction from Kellogg. He describes a meeting with Emilie Lawrence and Blossom Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Darrell C. Crain to Philip Showalter Hench, March 30, 1942
div1.opener:
DARRELL C. CRAIN, M. D.
1150 Connecticut Avenue
Washington, D.C.
March 30, 1942
INTERNAL MEDICINE; ARTHRITIS
Dr. Philip Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Phil:-
div1.p:
The enlargements arrived last week and I am delighted with
them. I had no idea that you had such a pretentious project
in mind but should have known it would be done with the
typical Hench gusto.

I have delayed writing you until I was able to secure the
autographs of Mrs. Reed and Blossom. Since the latter
seems to be out to lunch most of the time, it was only
yesterday that I was able to do this. I thought both of
them looked very good (the originals-not the autographs),
although Blossom assured me that “granny was cracking up
bad”. A framed picture of the eminent Dr. Hench hangs
conspicuously on the wall and Blossom “thought he was just
a dear to send it”.

Several days ago I received a letter from Mr. George Kellogg
in Jersey City, New Jersey, stating that he was forwarding
me a print of the picture, “Conquerors of Yellow Fever”, at
your request. This, too, has just arrived and is framed
very beautifully. I appreciate your thinking of me in this
regard.

Again thank you for all these favors. Give my best regards
to all the family.
div1.closer: Sincerely, Darrell C. Crain, M. D. DCC/om
